Authors: Regnier A.L., Hammerstedt S.W., Beale N.H.
Title: The Grobin Davis site: Archaeogeophysics and settlement patterns at Caddo mound centers in Southeastern Oklahoma
Abstract: The Grobin Davis site (34MC253) is the best-preserved known prehistoric Caddo mound site in southeastern Oklahoma. The site, located along the Little River, consists of seven mounds arranged in a horseshoe configuration. Archaeological excavations at the site have been limited to a series of posthole tests and three 1-x-l-m units. Between November 2011 and February 2012, the Oklahoma Archeological Survey conducted geophysical survey of the bulk of the site, covering approximately 32, 000 m2with a fluxgate gradiometer. This study provides important information about Caddo mound construction, settlement, and ceremonialism in southeastern OK and add to a growing body of literature on prehistoric Caddo community patterns.
Index Keywords: archaeology; excavation; geophysical survey; prehistoric; settlement pattern; Georgia; Little River [Georgia]; Oklahoma [United States]; United States
